title: At close of business on 5 November 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 16 September 2020?
preds: With many economists worried about a slumping recovery there is effectively no chance that the Fed will raise the federal funds rate. Additionally, recent comments by Jerome Powell have suggested that the Fed will consider alternative measures to assist the economy rather than just the federal funds rate. Lastly, The fed has said on numerous occasions that they do not support the use of a below 0 federal funds rate, which strengthens my idea that the federal funds rate will remain the same.
FOMC dotplot does not indicate changes
Fed has committed not to increase the rates for the time being

In April, June and July they issued this statement:
"In light of these developments, the Committee decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent.  The Committee expects to maintain this target range until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals. "[1] Have a really hard time seeing anything radically change in the coming months so changing my prediction to a certainty it will be the same.  Lower: -10
Same: +15
Higher: -5 1. https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm Check the statements.
It is predicted to rise for the year 2021, so it should go higher.
Confirmation from FOMC of expectation to hold range.
To now, I was convinced same. USA is already at negative rates in reality and have seen some mulling of slight reduction to keep that stock market bubble expanding. Thinking about 1% lower...
Stock markets are getting too much ahead of the main street. Maybe Feds will use higher funds rate to cool down the markets

The US just had its worst economic quarter since WW2 and the rate range is currently identical to that during the peak of the Great Recession. To go lower would require a negative rate range, which Fed chairman Jerome Powell has said is inappropriate for the US economy. While there is a small chance it will change this stance, the most likely scenario is that they will maintain its current level until the economy has rebounded from the pandemic, which is not likely to have subsided significantly enough to warrant a change by November.

Federal funds rate currently (7/14/2020) at .25.  It's possible the rate will go to at or near zero prior to the election but it's most likely to remain unchanged.  Due to Covid the reduction or increase in rates is without impact as businesses aren't aggressively seeking funds for business.
Investor confidence in an economic recovery will prove disappointing.
I don't believe they can go lower and the virus and large unemployment numbers points toward difficulties for the economy for long enough that I don't expect rates to increase by the end of the year.
With the outcome of the election still unknown, but Biden being the presumed winner on November 5, the fed will act

The risks on the economy are to the downside however the Fed will not want to be negative. It could occur for a short period if the economy significantly declines. Therefore it will remain the same. The Fed would need evidence of a sustained recovery or increasing inflation which will not occur before November.
Can't really go lower.  Higher might be a show to make a point about the economy improving, but it's too likely to suffer a backlash I think
Cant really go lower and economics cannot afford it to go higher.

Nobody is forecasting a change in the rates even in a longer period of time. Will be really odd to have a change. Reduce the rates means go to the negative, can happen for a short period of time, but this will be a tax for banks. As a result the economy will frozen. No country with negative rates can rule the economic world. I doubt US will risk his crown. On the other hand an inflationary shock should force FOMC to higher rates. I doubt will be the case in such a short period of time. Even if it happens, FED will react very slowly and cautionary.

Current target rate is 0 - 0.25%
For upper limit to go lower, Fed would have to adopt a Negative Interest Rate Policy. A couple of other central banks (ECB and Japanese Central Bank) have had NIRP for quite some time.
For Fed to adopt NIRP, the macroeconomic situation due to COVID has to become substantially worse. In case the economic recovery is slow then the Fed will probably continue using QE like tools to stimulate without a NIRP. The probability of rates going up even if the economic recovery is stronger than expectation is quite low given the presidential election and past Fed track-record of rate increases.

The Fed is one of the few institutions in the Trump era that does not seem to be excessively politicized. For the rate to change as a result of presidential elections would imply that the election of Biden or re election of Trump had somehow released a political obligation that the Fed had to Trump.

Let's first look at the outside view. The past four recessions (July 1981-December 1982, July 1991-February 1992, April-October 2001, December 2007-July 2009) have all coincided with steep rate cuts to soften the blow to the economy. The difference being in this scenario that there is no further to cut, at least not with having negative rates. [1] But the US has never had negative rates in comparison to Europe. The difference being that historically the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan have struggled with structural issues making it difficult to generate growth. [2] This should give us a solid indication that it is unlikely the Fed will allow rates to dip below zero. Time of writing, they sit at 0.05%.  On the other hand, Assistant Vice President of the St Louis Fed Yi Wen warns that a massive quantitative easing program may not be enough to facilitate a V-shaped recovery. He goes on to suggest negative interest rates among other policy tools may be the solution. [3] However, despite rallies in the stock market and typical CNBC guff that retail traders 'nailed the bottom' hopes of a V-shaped recovery are fading quickly. [4] Bloomberg reported last week that a second wave is emerging in the US and should this be the case it is unlikely that a rate cut will have much of an impact as the economic shutdown clock resets. [5] While a second lockdown phase is unlikely the damage will already be done. In the midst of all this, Chairman Powell has doubled down on his refusal to let rates go negative, seemingly preferring a QE-based strategy. The evidence, he says, just doesn't support them being an effective tool. A position on which all 17 FOMC members are agreed.[6] In sum, I'm not ruling out Powell having to climb down and cut rates but I think it's very unlikely. I also don't see any legitimate reason for the Fed to raise rates at this point unless it wants to watch the world implode. Rates will stay as they are barring an unforeseen developments. Please comment any critiques below. I would be delighted to hear them. [1] https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDFUNDS
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecb-policy-rates-explainer/explainer-how-does-negative-interest-rates-policy-work-idUSKCN1VY1D2
[3]https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2020/may/achieve-shaped-recovery-covid19-pandemic
[4] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/15/robinhood-traders-nailed-the-market-bottom-debunking-myth-retail-traders-are-the-dumb-money.html
[5] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-06-11/second-u-s-virus-wave-emerges-video
[6] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/powell-rejects-using-negative-rates-as-a-policy-tool-2020-05-13#:~:text=Federal%20Reserve%20Chairman%20Jerome%20Powell,rates%20really%20has%20not%20changed.
There is no desire for negative rates. The rates will be unchanged from September 16 to November 5.

They won't raise rates ever, certainly not in the next 5 years. Powell said they are "not thinking about thinking about raising rates". They kept rates at 0 for about seven years, and things are worse now. The last time they tried to raise rates in late 2018 they crashed the market and the stock market had the worst December since the great depression. They might be stupid enough to go negative if the economy gets worse.
Whitehouse disrespect for Fed, and advisors beyond Fox.
Expecting a clear Democratic victory in presidential and congressional elections.

Leaning into an election lower rates will support the current administration. A bump in the S&P just prior to the election is the best indicator of re-election.  A new administration may lean against a fed chair that has been somewhat pliable in response to Trump Tweets.
can't go lower, unlikely to have enough by nov to go higher, also wont want to move before election
Fed fund rate is 0 bound with no upside reason through 2021 or later...
This is the Fed road map, the Fed has very little wiggle room.

Rate currently low because economy bad. I think it will stay bad through nov 5.  It’s almost zero now and I don’t think the higher limit will go negative, so less chance of downward slide.  If Biden wins it might go higher, but probably that won’t be reflected at the November meeting
To mich Money in the market

Taking into account the current status of the US economy, and with a grim outlook for the coming months. I would guarantee we will not see higher rates. Although negative rates have been talked about, I believe this would a last ditch effort to stop the NYSE from going into an absolute free fall. So keeping them at current rates seems to be the most probably in my opinion.

Most likely outcome is that the rate is so low it can’t be lowered further.  There is high likelihood of significant pandemic impact and significant political pressure to keep the same rate or lower it.

In its recent meeting,  the Fed projected the short-term federal funds rate  to stay at zero until 2022. 
given the extremely high unemployment in the economy and slow recovery following the last three recessions,  I do not expect short term rate to move at all.
I do not believe that the Fed will lower the rate so close to the election.
Fed will be intimidated by Trump who will insist on lower rates.
Don't expect the corona virus related issues to go away this year. There's a slight chance with a new administration in November there could be a rethink

The Fed will be keeping interest rates at the same level or lower it slightly.  Their is very little wiggle room for the Fed to lower interest rates to help the economy.  The Fed will not raise the interest in a recession as that would hurt the economy.

Economy likely to suffer with Covid19 and elevated unemployment. Nasty presidential election will raise tension as well. All of these are negative. Inflation unlikely to change wildly in the short term. Finally, Fed will stay away from influencing the election (customary).
Fed Chairman has indicated they are not likely to raise rates until 2023. The rate is very low and unless the economy worsens significantly it will remain the same.
The Fed will likely keep this rate stable for the rest of the year. There is no need to change it in the short term.
The economy will still be in a recession and will need low interest rates.  The fed will either keep it the same or lower it more.  Chances are more that they keep it the same.
Fed has said they are not even thinking about thinking of raising rates until 2022.
I read a few articles over time

With rate as low as it ever been there is not much wiggle room to go down. With current economic crisis, which I see continuing for at least the rest of the year, they want to keep the rate low. So most likely it'll be the same. Leaving some room for movement of the rate, with double the chance of lower compared to higher rate.

Funds rate probabilities are bounded by three main functions.  The most important at this time is economic pressure due to Covid19.  This pressure will require the release of certain economic and monetary pressures by the Fed.  Fluctuations in this pressure week to week requires a strictly bounded range of possible fund rates to achieve stability in the monetary systems in the US and abroad.

While the Fed is highly reluctant to adopt negative interest rates for the world's reserve currency, a second wave of economic shutdowns due to Coronavirus spikes could force the Fed to take a "carrot and stick" approach to keep commercial paper flowing. The carrot will be backstopping overnight loans, but bipartisan political pressure to penalize banks will pressure the Fed to add a stick.  The governors could then choose negative interest rates to incentivize well-capitalized banks to keep lending in the overnight markets. This move may only ameliorate, not alleviate, the political pressure, but it will align bank management with Federal policy and help avoid a liquidity freeze. Bankers know they have to signal their concerns for taxpayers next time around.
If Trump is still in office and the economy continues to struggle there will be significant Governmental (Trump) pressure on the Fed to make further cuts in anticipation of the Presidential election.
The rate is very low now and unless the economy collapses, I believe it will remain stable.
It’s unlikely feds will make it harder for banks to borrow money
The extent of the economic impact of covid-19 will not be fully realized unless the case rate spikes dramatically in the fall.  The fed will lower the current rate in an effort to spur borrowing.
With the exception of 2019, it has remained the same for the past 5 years. Recent comments from the department also confirmed intending the hold the rate steady through 2022.

Federal funds rate is currently between 0% - 0.25% as of March during the drop - https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/15/federal-reserve-cuts-rates-to-zero-and-launches-massive-700-billion-quantitative-easing-program.html - Per Wiki, "When the Federal Open Market Committee wishes to reduce interest rates they will increase the supply of money by buying government securities." The Fed has been slowing down their purchase of treasury bonds (govt securities) after planning to buy $75B per day in March. Last week, they planned to purchase $4B per day (https://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/domestic-market-operations/monetary-policy-implementation/treasury-securities/treasury-securities-operational-details) - When the Fed rate was higher (1% - 1.25%), the Fed planned to purchase $20B in treasuries per month (see previous link). However, the Fed is planning to purchase $80B of treasuries per month over the next month, given that there's uncertainty in the market (relative to the economy). - CME group publishes a "Fed watch tool" that predicts the Fed reserve rate. It's currently predicting a 100% probability that it continues to be unchanged between 0% - 0.25% (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html). Can't find much evidence for previous accuracy, but they had a 80% chance of 0%-0.25% in Dec for April's reserve rate (5 months prior). Conclusion:
- Fed to keep it same (0% - 0.25%), but cannot rule out negative rates if markets align with the economy.

1) The Fed been very clear that they don't intend to raise the rates anytime soon. 
2) The Fed is willing to use other instruments in order to stimulate the economy (including pushing the Congress to pass more fiscal stimulus)
3) The Fed would like to retain the current 0.00% - 0.25% range and would like to avoid cutting to 0.00% (where would they go next?) So starting off with: Lower (V slim chances)     - 3%
Same (pretty much)         - 97%
Higher (no way by Nov)   - 0%
We know it won't be higher through 2022... or something like that. I'll find my source later.
Can’t go much lower. Don’t see any reason for it to be higher.
Feds just said today they do not plan to change the rate through the rest of the year to help economic growth.
This is getting to be a boring question. The Fed will be accomdative until 2022 and won't go negative. The Fed doesn't want to be seen as being influenced by politics and this is an election quarter.

The Fed isn't likely to do much around an election, plus it can't go down much and they have already stated they plan on keeping rates low. The leads me to be pretty confident it will be the same. I'll likely make this 90% in a couple months, barring some odd economic news.

This meeting is two days after the Presidential Election, and I don’t think the Fed Reserve will make a rate change right after elections. Additionally, going lower would essentially put rates at zero, which is admitting a recession or worse a depression. Fed will keep rates the same until at least 2021 when the pandemic is over and jobs start coming back.

Very unlikely that the FOMC would make a change less than a week after the Presidential election.  There would need to have been extraordinary event for any move in that time frame.   Could be a lot of change with the FOMC following meeting.
